thread.title: Does your ability to smell predict your death?
thread.title_full: Does your ability to smell predict your death? - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: Marvin Harris
title: Does your ability to smell predict your death?
text:
(RNN) - The better your sense of smell, researchers say, the longer you might live.
Implications for humans might be derived from the findings that roundworms with a failing sense of smell died sooner than worms with normal ability, said researchers at the Salk Institute, a nonprofit founded by Jonas Salk, the developer of the polio vaccine.
“We’re not saying that your ability to smell is going to make you live longer,” Sreekanth Chalasani , an assistant professor in Salk’s Molecular Neurobiology Laboratory, said in a news release . “But this odor behavior is likely indicative of some kind of underlying physiology.”
Their research, published in the journal eLife , predicted whether worms would be long-lived by how fast they moved toward a foodlike scent.
People and animals, including worms, often start to lose their sense of smell as they age, the researchers said. So they set out to determine whether poor performance on a smell-based test indicated an animal’s lifespan.
“Older animals that were more successful in finding the odor lived about 16 percent longer than animals that were less good at moving toward the smell,” the researchers said.
Many questions remain about what changes as animals age,” said Sarah Leinwand, a graduate student and the author of the paper. “We want to keep looking at what is changing to cause some animals to have better functioning nervous systems and to live longer."
